occurrences.line_text: Whiles thus we suffer this same dotard old,
Then said Cymochles; Palmer, thou doest dote,
The Prince halfe rapt, began on her to dote:
Whose senceless speach, and doted ignorance
Like Phoebus lampe throughout the world doth shine,
Foule Errour doth defeate:
Doth to his home entreate.
He brusheth oft, and oft doth mar their murmurings.
But if of daunger which hereby doth dwell,
In which that wicked wight his dayes doth weare:
At night doth baite his steedes the Ocean waues emong.
To Morpheus house doth hastily repaire.
And low, where dawning day doth neuer peepe,
Doth euer wash, and Cynthia still doth steepe
Doth euer wash, and Cynthia still doth steepe
Whiles sad Night ouer him her ma[n]tle black doth spred
By them the Sprite doth passe in quietly,
Or the blind God, that doth me thus amate,
Come see, where your false Lady doth her honour staine.
Yet rests not so, but other meanes doth make,
And high hath set his throne, where Tiberis doth pas.
Nor guilefull sprite, to thee these wordes doth speake,
Where Boreas doth blow full bitter bleake,
Quoth she, his princely puissance doth abate,
And at her feet the Lyon watch doth keepe:
Encountring fierce, him suddaine doth surprize,
His chearefull whistle merrily doth sound,
He hurles out vowes, and Neptune oft doth blesse:
Enough is, that thy foe doth vanquisht stand
His hastie hand he doth amazed hold,
doth chalenge him to fight.
That doth this Redcrosse knights ensample plainly proue.
And thundring Ioue, that high in heauen doth dwell,
The royall Dame, and for her coche doth call:
Out of the East the dawning day doth call:
So forth she comes: her brightnesse brode doth blaze;
Her glorious glitterand light doth all mens eyes amaze.
His almes for want of faith he doth accuse;
So euery good to bad he doth abuse:
From wandring Stygian shores, where it doth endlesse moue.
With greedy force each other doth assayle,
The cruell steele so greedily doth bight
Alone he wandring thee too long doth want:
Goe say, his foe thy shield with his doth beare.
Vpon him fell: he no where doth appeare,
Doth meet a cruell craftie Crocodile,
Doth weepe full sore, and sheddeth tender teares:
Lo where the stout Sansioy doth sleepe in deadly shade.
She more amaz'd, in double dread doth dwell;
So from the ground she fearelesse doth arise,
And Pholoe fowle, when her to this he doth compaire.
Not far away (quoth he) he hence doth wonne
Most sencelesse man he, that himselfe doth hate,
By which deceipt doth maske in visour faire,
Who with his breath, which through the world doth pas,
Conceiueth fire, the heauens it doth fill
With thundring noyse, and all the ayre doth choke,
A liue or dead: and forward forth doth pas,
As when a cloud his beames doth ouer-lay;
Remedilesse, for aie he doth him hold;
Were not, that heauenly grace doth him vphold,
For whose deliuera[n]ce she this Prince doth thither guide.
In which my Lord my liege doth lucklesse lie,
An heard of Bulles, whom kindly rage doth sting,
Doth roll adowne the rocks, and fall with fearefull drift.
And this misseeming hew your manly looks doth marre?
My chaster Muse for shame doth blush to write;
Whilome doth rancle in my riuen brest,
Doth soonest fall in disauentrous fight,
His powre is reft, and weaknesse doth remaine.
That still for carrion carcases doth craue:
And meetes a flood, that doth his passage stay,
Doth license him depart at sound of morning droome.
The further he doth goe, the further he doth stray.
The further he doth goe, the further he doth stray.
Is not he iust, that all this doth behold
The which doth quench the brond of hellish smart,
And that accurst hand-writing doth deface,
Which all so soone, as it doth come to fight,
Or from the field most cowardly doth fly?
As hoarie frost with spangles doth attire
By wise Fidelia? she doth thee require,
Whose staggering steps thy steady hand doth lead,
Wherein eternall peace and happinesse doth dwell.
In which that fairest Faerie Queene doth dwell,
What need of armes, where peace doth ay remaine,
Whose sight my feeble soule doth greatly cheare:
As mountaine doth the valley ouercast.
His aery plumes doth rouze, full rudely dight,
As chauffed Bore his bristles doth vpreare,
His wearie pounces all in vaine doth spend,
Whom famous Poetes verse so much doth vaunt,
Doth belch out flames, and rockes in peeces broke,
And rolling downe, great Neptune doth dismay;
When morning deaw vpon their leaues doth light:
Her dearely doth imbrace, and kisseth manifold.
As bright as doth the morning starre appeare
What woman, and wherefore doth me vpbrayd
In whom great rule of Temp'raunce goodly doth appeare.
The stricke[n] Deare doth chalenge by the bleeding wound.
The which good fortune doth to you present.
When ill is chaunst, but doth the ill increase,
And now he doth himselfe in secret shrowd,
Brayes out her latest breath, and vp her eyes doth seele.
The bitter pangs, that doth your heart infest.
Within a wandring Island, that doth ronne
For he was flesh: (all flesh doth frailtie breed.)
Religious reuerence doth buriall teene,
Does ride on both their backs, & faire her selfe doth saue.
That more to mighty ha[n]ds, the[n] rightfull cause doth trust.
Ne ought the prayse of prowesse more doth marre,
Doth nourish vertue, and fast friendship breeds;
And inly grieue, as doth an hidden moth
This thy demaund, ï¿½ Lady, doth reuiue
And in her face faire peace, and mercy doth appeare.
The day that first doth lead the yeare around;
Ill by ensample good doth often gayne.
As Peacocke, that his painted plumes doth prancke,
Doth beare the fairest flowre in honorable seed.
But it were that, which noblest knight on earth doth weare.
For neither doth thy face terrestriall shew,
And euill meanes, with which she doth enrage
What great despight doth fortune to thee beare,
His be that care, whom most it doth concerne,
Who euer doth to temperaunce apply
But to be lesser, then himselfe, doth marre
Vaine others ouerthrowes, who selfe doth ouerthrowe.
Or sweetnesse doth allure the weaker sence
Will die for thirst, and water doth refuse?
The wind vnstable, and doth neuer stay.
(So Loue the dread of daunger doth despise)
Regard of worldly mucke doth fowly blend,
Sometimes to him, that low in dust doth ly?
That noble heart as great dishonour doth despize.
Who swelling sayles in Caspian sea doth crosse,
And in frayle wood on Adrian gulfe doth fleet,
Doth not, I weene, so many euils meet.
Vntroubled Nature doth her selfe suffise,
Doth dim with horrour and deformitie,
And all his workes with mercy doth embrace,
And mortall arrowes, wherewith he doth fill
Whiles deadly fit thy pupill doth dismay;
The charge, which God doth vnto me arret,
Loe where he now inglorious doth lye,
Yet gold all is not, that doth golden seeme,
Or what doth his bad death now satisfy
Is sacrilege, and doth all sinnes exceed;
Doth promise hope of helpe, and timely grace,
The trespasse still doth liue, albe the person die.
Dyes not, when breath the bodie first doth leaue,
And all his seed the curse doth often cleaue,
So streightly God doth iudge. But gentle knight,
That doth against the dead his hand vpreare,
Whom foe with double battry doth assaile,
Loe where the dreadfull Death behind thy backe doth stond.
When rancour doth with rage him once engore,
But vse thy fortune, as it doth befall,
doth sober Alma dwell,
Doth loose his dignitie and natiue grace.
Doth blesse her seruaunts, and them high aduaunce.
Heauen doth to me enuy, and fortune fauourlesse.
A Lyon and a Tigre doth espye,
That as a cloud doth seeme to dim the skies;
Doth blow them quite away, and in the Ocean cast.
From whence it doth, as cloud from sea arise.
That all this other worlds worke doth excell,
As all things else, the which this world doth weld,
By which all earthly Princes she doth farre surmount.
Yet doth it selfe stretch forth to heauens hight,
That monstrous error, which doth some assot,
Which Seuerne now from Logris doth depart:
Whom antique history so high doth raise,
And ample volume, that doth far excead
Maleger doth deface.
But in a body, which doth freely yeeld
Doth florish in all beautie excellent:
And to her guestes doth bounteous banket dight,
And the sad husbandmans long hope doth throw
With murmurous disdaine doth inly raue,
And vnto better fortune doth her selfe prepaire.
Doth ouerthrow the Bowre of blisse,
He soone in vomit vp againe doth lay,
Ouer the waues his rugged armes doth lift,
Then he with all his puissance doth striue
To strike his oares, and mightily doth driue
Doth rore at them in vaine, and with great terror raue.
Yet well they seeme to him, that farre doth vew,
For twixt them both the narrow way doth ly.
The horrible Sea-satyre, that doth shew
The Whistler shrill, that who so heares, doth dy,
And straunge phantomes doth let vs oft forsee,
Yet each doth in him selfe it well perceiue to bee.
That secretly doth vs procure to fall,
It selfe doth offer to his sober eye,
And that, which all faire workes doth most aggrace,
His deawy face out of the sea doth reare:
Doth first peepe forth with bashfull modestee,
Her bared bosome she doth broad display;
Ne more doth flourish after first decay,
Yet now my lucklesse lot doth me constraine
All as a blazing starre doth farre outcast
That euery knight, which doth this way repaire,
That for his trusty seruaunts doth so strongly fight.
Which by her owne law to your lot doth light,
For who can shun the chaunce, that dest'ny doth ordaine?
But wishing it far off, his idle wish doth lose.
And to faire semblaunce doth light faith annexe;
Into his hidden net full easily doth fall.
Doth light the lower world, were halfe yspent,
Endite I would as dewtie doth excite;
Doth not so much reioyce, as she reioyced theare.
Where so he heares, that any doth confound
That doth the charmed Snake in slomber lay:
Betwixt two shadie mountaines doth arize;
Of hurt vnwist most daunger doth redound:
Then doth this wicked euill thee infest,
For nought for me but death there doth remaine.
It is, ï¿½ Nurse, which on my life doth feed,
And suckes the bloud, which from my hart doth bleed.
But rather doth my helpelesse griefe augment.
Not that same, which doth base affections moue
But that sweet fit, that doth true beautie loue,
To order them, as best to thee doth seeme,
Tormenteth, and doth plonge in dolefull plight,
But this sad euill, which doth her infest,
Doth course of naturall cause farre exceed,
Or euill spright, that in her doth such torment breed.
Doth by her blushing tell, that she did lye
From where the day out of the sea doth spring,
That of the time doth dew aduauntage take;
Ye see that good king Vther now doth make
That now all Britanie doth burne in armes bright.
Vpblowing, doth disperse the vapour lo'st,
Doth groueling fall, and with his streaming gore
And safest seemes, him soonest doth amate,
Who dyes the vtmost dolour doth abye,
Which after her his nimble wings doth straine,
The slouthfull bodie, that doth loue to steepe
Doth praise thee oft, and oft from Stygian deepe
And his large bountie rightly doth areed.
Our life is day, but death with darknesse doth begin.
How diuersly loue doth his pageants play,
That to all high desert and honour doth aspire.
But to his first poursuit him forward still doth call.
And doth for wretched mens reliefe make way;
Thy life she gaue, thy life she doth deserue:
And doth not highest God vouchsafe to take
When the bright sunne his beams thereon doth beat;
Of woman kind it fairest flowre doth spire,
All other pleasant places doth excell,
Wherewith dame Nature doth her beautifie,
But so much as doth need, must needs be counted here.
Becomes a bodie, and doth then inuade
Doth it consume, and into nothing go,
As doth the lilly fresh before the sunny ray.
Pleasure, that doth both gods and men aggrate,
That fortune all in equall launce doth sway,
And mortall miseries doth make her play.
On the bright Sunne vnwares, doth soone withdraw
The wofull husbandman doth lowd complaine,
Like as a Goshauke, that in foote doth beare
An Egle, that with plumy wings doth sheare
And to the battell doth her selfe prepare:
Through her maine strength, in which she most doth trust,
My hart doth melt with meere compassion,
So much high God doth innocence embrace.
Which with her loose incontinence doth blend
Whose beauty doth her bounty far surpasse,
Confounds both land & seas, and skyes doth ouercast.
To turne she doth refuse.
Ne doth he suffer her, nor night, nor day,
So doth he punish her and eke himselfe torment.
That doth with curelesse care consume the hart,
And doth transfixe the soule with deathes eternall dart.
And doth himselfe with sorrow new sustaine,
Sweet Loue, that doth his golding wings embay
Or doth thy iustice sleepe, and silent ly?
And the sharpe steele doth riue her hart in tway,
Because to yield him loue she doth deny,
For nothing so much pitty doth implore,
Perceth the yielding ayre, and doth displace
Such as false loue doth oft vpon him weare:
For loue in thousand monstrous formes doth oft appeare.
My looser rimes (I wote) doth sharply wite,
My softened heart so sorely doth constraine,
And all dissention, which doth dayly grow
And many a priuate oft doth ouerthrow.
Like as a gloomie cloud, the which doth beare
Quite ouerblowne, yet doth not passe so cleare,
But that it all the skie doth ouercast
For her that each of you alike doth loth,
Why doth mine hand from thine auenge abstaine,
doth lengthen her sonnes liues.
Since so good fortune doth to you present
That doth ill cause or euill end enure:
But wicked Time that all good thoughts doth waste,
How may these rimes, so rude as doth appeare,
Of thine owne spirit, which doth in me suruiue,
And like that roote that doth her life diuide,
doth their long strife agree.
Yet is as nigh his end, as he that most doth playne.
At puffe of euery storme doth stagger here and theare.
But to forbeare doth not forgiue the det.
Through hunger long, that hart to him doth lend,
Casts off his ragged skin and freshly doth him dight.
Like to the rod which Maias sonne doth wield,
Wherewith the hellish fiends he doth confound.
It doth establish in the troubled mynd.
But this doth hatred make in loue to brenne,
And heauy heart with comfort doth reioyce.
And Artegall doth quell.
Like as a Lion that by chaunce doth fall
Into the hunters toile, doth rage and rore,
Doth burne the earth, and boyled riuers drie,
A watry cloud doth ouercast the skie,
doth sleepe from him expell.
For either doth on other much relie.
And she most fit his seruice doth deserue,
In which to her that doth the most excell,
But whosoeuer contrarie doth proue,
With golden foyle doth finely ouer spred
He much more goodly glosse thereon doth shed,
But now of Britomart it here doth neede,
He sees her face; doth fall in loue,
Yeeld such a sore, that doth her grieuance hide,
Did leape to her, as doth an eger hound
Which battring, downe it on the church doth glance,
That where ye left, I may her seeke, as doth behoue.
That yet of mortall stroke the stound doth beare.
For vertues onely sake, which doth beget
his dayes in dole doth lead.
Death is to him, that wretched life doth lead,
Both grace and gaine; but he in hell doth lie,
For on the spoile of women he doth liue,
He with his shamefull lust doth first deflowre,
And afterwards themselues doth cruelly deuoure.
Who trussing me, as Eagle doth his pray,
To banish sloth, that oft doth noble mindes annoy.
Doth hast to crosse him by the nearest way,
Sclaunder her guests doth staine:
As blasted bloosme through heat doth languish & decay;
Or selfe disliked life doth thee thus wretched make?
The grace of his Creator doth despise,
That any bud thereof doth scarse remaine,
Like as a curre doth felly bite and teare
From powrefull eyes close venim doth conuay
Though namelesse there his bodie now doth lie,
For naturall affection soone doth cesse,
But faithfull friendship doth them both suppresse,
And them with maystring discipline doth tame,
For as the soule doth rule the earthly masse,
So loue of soule doth loue of bodie passe,
As when an eager mastiffe once doth proue
Long here and there, and round about doth stie,
Scudamour doth his conquest tell,
That loue with gall and hony doth abound,
A pound of gall doth ouer it redound.
And vnto Venus grace the gate doth open right.
Then doth the dï¿½dale earth throw forth to thee
Where Thames doth the Medway wedd,
Old Styx the Grandame of the Gods, doth lay.
And huge Orion, that doth tempests still portend.
The waters depth, and doth their bottome tread;
The fertile Nile, which creatures new doth frame;
And that huge Riuer, which doth beare his name
Or Arts, but Oxford thine doth Thame most glorify.
When to Ioues pallace she doth take her way;
The wanton Lee, that oft doth loose his way,
That doth his course through Blandford plains direct,
That of his wylinesse his name doth take,
And of him selfe doth name the shire thereby;
And Mole, that like a nousling Mole doth make
And Clare, and Harwitch both doth beautify:
Thence doth by Huntingdon and Cambridge flit;
He doth adorne, and is adorn'd of it
Whose bad condition yet it doth retaine,
That to old Loncaster his name doth lend;
Did call diuine, that doth by Chester tend;
And Conway which out of his streame doth send
And Lindus that his pikes doth most commend,
The third, the goodly Barow, which doth hoord
With Erato that doth in loue delite,
To see an helpelesse euill, double griefe doth lend.
Therefore to Tryphon she againe doth hast,
And him doth chyde as false and fraudulent,
That doth enlumine all these lesser fyres,
And twice hath risen, where he now doth West,
That powre he also doth to Princes lend,
And rule his people right, as he doth recommend.
This lucklesse Ladie, which now here doth headlesse lie.
In that same place, whereas it now doth lie.
Take here your owne, that doth you best beseeme,
Ne better doth beseeme braue cheualry,
A cursed cruell Sarazin doth wonne,
Is he, that doth to trauellers such harmes?
With which his daughter doth him still support;
Else he doth hold him backe or beat away.
Whose scalp is bare, that bondage doth bewray,
But he him selfe vppon th rich doth tyrannize.
That with his powre he all doth ouergo,
And some by sleight he eke doth vnderfong.
Through which the rider downe doth fall through ouersight.
All destitute of helpe doth headlong fall,
Then doth he take the spoile of them at will,
Who all that comes doth take, and therewith fill
But by that Bridge, whereas he doth abide:
Doth frie with fome aboue the surges hore.
And looke then how much it doth ouerflow,
In which it doth immoueable abide,
Such heauenly iustice doth among them raine,
For whatsoeuer from one place doth fall,
They liue, they die, like as he doth ordaine,
And weigh the winde, that vnder heauen doth blow;
Or weigh the light, that in the East doth rise;
Or weigh the thought, that fro[m] mans mind doth flow.
Weigh but one word which from thy lips doth fall.
The sunne at length his ioyous face doth cleare:
That with this present treatise doth agree,
By which that glorie gotten doth appeare.
Ne any token doth thereof abide:
Within his mouth a blacke spot doth appeare,
and doth from death repriue.
That, which he doth with righteous doome decide,
But tract of time, that all things doth decay,
And this deuouring Sea, that naught doth spare,
But not for it this ods twixt vs doth stand,
For equall right in equall things doth stand,
Which she could doe to Knights, which now she doth fulfill.
She doth subdue, she fowly doth entreate.
She doth subdue, she fowly doth entreate.
First she doth them of warlike armes despoile,
Doth them compell to worke, to earne their meat,
Ne doth she giue them other thing to eat,
And venge the shame, that she to Knights doth show.
Proudly stands ouer, and a while doth pause,
Her from the quarrey he away doth driue,
And from her griping pounce the greedy prey doth riue.
With his great yron sledge doth strongly on it beat.
Doth seeme to be her selfe, though darkned be her light.
Doth beat vpon the gentle bird in vaine,
But dread of shame my doubtfull lips doth still restraine.
Doth not your handmayds life at your foot lie?
Chiefely by him, whose life her law doth bynd,
From seeking fauour, where it doth abound;
That all his former praise doth fowly spill.
That from thy tongue thy hearts intent doth hold.
My Lord, your Loue, by hard mishap doth lie
With froward will doth set him selfe to weepe;
The Engin fiercely flying forth, doth teare
Th'one from the earth, & through the aire doth beare;
The other it with force doth ouerthrow,
Vppon one side, and from his rootes doth reare.
Then this same vertue, that doth right define:
Of highest Ioue, who doth true iustice deale
The skill whereof to Princes hearts he doth reueale.
To shew that Isis doth the Moone portend;
Ne feed on ought, the which doth bloud containe,
For by the holy vow, which me doth bind,
For that same Crocodile doth represent
That vnder Isis feete doth sleepe for euer:
Doth in defence thereof full stoutly stond:
To which the Lion strongly doth gainesay,
Nought vnder heauen so strongly doth allure
As beauties louely baite, that doth procure
Doe serue a Queene, that not far hence doth wone,
She doth support, and strongly beateth downe
Yet she her selfe the more doth magnify,
And all his powre doth thereunto apply:
To Iustice, and against her still doth fight,
That shone as bright, as doth the heauen sheene;
Doth runne at randon, and with furious bit
Snatching at euery thing, doth wreake her wrath
whom Talus doth dismay,
Where still the stronger doth the weake deuoure,
Through these his slights he many doth confound,
How he his nets doth for their ruine lay:
Yet neuer doth from doome of right depart:
To whom nought else, but bare life doth remaine,
Good hart in euils doth the euils much amend.
With such his chearefull speaches he doth wield
An hideous monster doth in darknesse lie,
Doth slay the Monster, and restore
That is the vertue selfe, which her reward doth pay.
And vnderneath this Idoll there doth lie
An hideous monster, that doth it defend,
It has the voice, that speaches forth doth send,
Euen blasphemous words, which she doth bray
What new ocasion doth thee hither driue,
Or is she thrall, or doth she not suruiue?
Of all those crimes, that he gainst her doth reare,
He day and night doth ward both far and wide,
For soone as he their outrage backe doth beat,
Like scattred chaffe, the which the wind away doth fan.
As to abandon, that which doth containe
Not so; (quoth he) for yet when time doth serue,
When as necessitie doth it constraine.
Of flyes vpon a birchen bough doth cluster,
As when the wrathfull Boreas doth bluster,
Whose goodly light then Phebus lampe doth shine more cleare?
Artegall doth Sir Burbon aide,
